discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. git revert

In this case, the developer would want to use the `git revert` command. This command creates a new commit that undoes the changes made in the previous commit. This is a safe way to undo changes, as it doesn't alter the existing history. 

The `git reset` command does undo changes, but it does so by discarding commits in a way that is potentially unsafe, as you can lose changes permanently.

The `git checkout` command is used to switch branches or restore working tree files, among its other uses.

The `git clean` command is used to remove untracked files from the working directory.

A developer is working in a branch to develop a new feature named 'newfeat404880077'. A file named 'devcoreg13642911.jpg' has accidentally been staged. This needs to be removed so that the commit is performed and branches merged. Which git command must be used to unstage the file?

B. git remove HEAD devcoreg13642911.jpg
C. git reset HEAD devcoreg13642911.jpg
D. git revert HEAD devcoreg13642911.jpg

The git command that should be used to unstage the file 'devcoreg13642911.jpg' is:

C. git reset HEAD devcoreg13642911.jpg

To unstage the file to current commit (HEAD):
git reset HEAD <file>
https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/topics/git/undo.html

To unstage file: git reset <commit> -- <path>

comments.content: It's clearly A. How could it be C or D? :)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Deploy Istio service mesh and enable mutual TLS for all the container pods.

Istio is a service mesh that provides traffic management, policy enforcement, and telemetry collection. One of Istio's key features is the ability to automatically enable mutual TLS for microservices communication, providing secure service-to-service communication in a cluster, including end-to-end encryption, strong identity-based authentication, and authorization.

While the other options may be part of a comprehensive security strategy, they do not directly address the requirement of end-to-end encryption of API communications between microservices in a Kubernetes environment.

questions.question_text: How should end-to-end encryption of API communications be applied between the microservices containers of the application in a Kubernetes environment?

choices.B: Modify the application code to instrument encryption of the API communication endpoints.
choices.A: Set up the network policy on the deployment.
choices.C: Ensure that container pods are deployed with non-root privileges to enforce encryption.
choices.D: Deploy Istio service mesh and enable mutual TLS for all the container pods.

questions.question_text:
A development team is considering options for implementing a new configuration management solution which must:
• be agentless
• utilize Python as a developing language
• leverage YAML based workflows

Which solution must be chosen?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
At its core, Ansible operates in an “agentless” fashion. This means you’re freed from the hassle of installing and maintaining agent software on the nodes you manage. Simply put, all you need is SSH access, and you’re good to go. This simplicity is one of the cornerstones of Ansible’s broad appeal. 

Yet Ansible’s human-readable declarative language, YAML, truly sets it apart. Users can quickly outline and execute complex tasks using playbooks—YAML scripts defining configurations and tasks. These playbooks provide a straightforward, structured method to represent automation workflows, making them easy to write and understand. 

https://netboxlabs.com/blog/nornir-vs-ansible-how-to-choose/

Selected Answer: C
Why not Nornir: Nornir is a Python library for managing network devices, not a complete configuration management solution. It wouldn't offer the full feature set needed by the development team.

comments.content: you do, when you develop modules. So it is C - Ansible

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct. 
you do not really use python as a developing language but rather a backend implementation for Ansible

Selected Answer: C
C - Ansible
It is more suited then Nornir to leverage YAML based workflows.

questions.question_text: What is an advantage of using gRPC dial-in when using model-driven telemetry on a device?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Agree with B.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/asr9000/software/710x/telemetry/configuration/guide/b-telemetry-cg-asr9000-710x/scale-up-your-network-monitoring-strategy-using-telemetry.html#id_117897:~:text=Dial%2DIn%20Mode-,In%20a%20dial%2Din%20mode,-%2C%20a%20collector%20dials

Selected Answer: B
Since the collector “dials-in” to the router, there’s no need to specify each MDT destination in the configuration. Just enable the gRPC service on the router, connect your client, and dynamically enable the telemetry subscription you want.
https://xrdocs.io/telemetry/blogs/2017-01-20-model-driven-telemetry-dial-in-or-dial-out/

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
Dial-In (dynamic): Telemetry updates are sent to the initiator subscriber

A is not correct: it tries to re-establish/re-initiate and not recover the connection
C is not correct: to configure a gRPC stream is dial-out
D is not correct: this is NETCONF

Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/switches/catalyst-9300-series-switches/model-driven-telemetry-wp.html#DialinanddialoutMDT

Selected Answer: A
B is correct
Dial-In (dynamic): Telemetry updates are sent to the initiator subscriber

A is not correct: it tries to re-establish/re-initiate and not recover the connection
C is not correct: to configure a gRPC stream is dial-out 
D is not correct: this is NETCONF

Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/switches/catalyst-9300-series-switches/model-driven-telemetry-wp.html#DialinanddialoutMDT

Selected Answer: A
A. automatically recover in the event of a lost connection

gRPC dial-in model has the advantage of automatically recovering in the event of a lost connection. In this model, the telemetry collector initiates the connection to the network device, and if the connection is lost for any reason, the collector can automatically attempt to reestablish the connection. This automatic recovery feature helps to improve the reliability of telemetry data collection and reduce the likelihood of data loss.

The other options (B, C, and D) do not accurately describe the advantages of using gRPC dial-in in the context of model-driven telemetry.

choices.B: no need to specify an explicit destination for data
choices.C: telemetry collector dials into the device to configure a gRPC stream
choices.A: automatically recover in the event of a lost connection
